question_details.title: Will there be another deadly clash between Thailand and Cambodia, resulting in three or more fatalities, before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-30 21:28:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/39002). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

After a brief border conflict killing at least 20 military personnel on both sides, Thailand and Cambodia agreed to a ceasefire on July 28, 2025, which they [reaffirmed](https://apnews.com/article/thailand-cambodia-ceasefire-china-brokered-1970718e765717be6f7e3f69e0c006f3) two days later. Despite the ceasefire, skirmishes continued, including an [incident](https://en.freshnewsasia.com/index.php/en/localnews/62630-2025-07-30-08-31-00.html) in which up to 20 Cambodian troops were captured and possibly two killed on July 30, 2025. According to [Deutsche Welle](https://www.dw.com/en/will-the-cambodia-thailand-ceasefire-hold/a-73448995):

> Matthew Wheeler, a senior analyst for the International Crisis Group in Bangkok, said Monday's truce could take hold — as long as both sides "recognize their interests are better served by a ceasefire than further fighting."

> He said the deal could hit some snags over the details, though, including how exactly to monitor the ceasefire, which has yet to be worked out in full.

> Malaysia, as ASEAN chair, has offered to coordinate a monitoring team. But Wheeler says neither side is keen to host monitors from other countries.

> "There was a plan to introduce Indonesian observers under ASEAN auspices after fighting in 2011, but it never happened," he said. Even so, he added, "both militaries have in the past demonstrated a capacity to de-escalate after earlier rounds of fighting."

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":39002,"question_id":38336}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if, after July 31, 2025 and before January 1, 2026, there is a deadly clash between the military forces of Thailand and Cambodia, resulting in three or more total fatalities between both sides, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).
question_details.fine_print:
To count, a clash must either be [kinetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinetic_military_action) (using explosive weaponry) or involve physical violence such as the close-quarters combat that occurred at[ Galwan Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_China%E2%80%93India_skirmishes#Galwan_Valley_clash) between forces of India and China in June 2020. Non-kinetic or non-physical actions such as a cyberattack would not count, even ones resulting in deaths.

For the purposes of this question, “military forces” means

* personnel of the Royal Thai Armed Forces
* personnel of the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces
* law‑enforcement personnel of either state
* or any paramilitary or militia group allied with any of the above - for example, Thahan Phran (Thai Rangers).

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Tensions Between Thailand and Cambodia: Thai Military Detects New Landmines on Border**
Tailandia has accused Cambodia of violating the existing peace agreement after detecting new landmines along their shared border, following the injury of two Thai soldiers in a mine explosion the previous week. The Thai government and military presented evidence of the mine placements during a press conference, with government spokesperson Siripong Angskasakulkiat stating that Thailand will pursue bilateral mechanisms with Cambodia first, but reserves the right to escalate to multilateral measures if needed. He emphasized that Thailand will respond appropriately to provocations. Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nikorndej Balankura confirmed that Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul will send an official letter to U.S. President Donald Trump to reaffirm Thailand's position on suspending the Joint Declaration due to Cambodia's alleged breach. The letter, stemming from prior phone conversations, focuses solely on border security and excludes commercial issues. **Thai King’s Historic Visit to China Amid Border Tensions with Cambodia**
On November 13, 2025, King Maha Vajiralongkorn of Thailand arrived in Beijing, marking the first official state visit by a Thai monarch to China in decades. The visit was met with high-level Chinese hospitality, including a formal welcome ceremony and structured diplomatic talks, signaling the importance of Sino-Thai relations and being described by observers as a 'milestone' in regional diplomacy. However, on November 12, 2025, just one day before the king's arrival, intense gunfire erupted along the Thai-Cambodian border. Cambodia's Ministry of Defense accused Thai forces of opening fire on civilians, injuring five, and violating a ceasefire agreement. Thailand denied the claim, asserting that Cambodian troops initiated a 10-minute artillery exchange targeting a Thai border base, and stated it had maintained restraint despite being prepared to respond. This clash ended a fragile ceasefire that had lasted less than a month. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet swiftly ordered border troops to full alert and deployed reinforcements, reaffirming his hardline stance established during a similar conflict in July 2025. The underlying cause of the conflict is the longstanding, unresolved border dispute spanning over 800 kilometers, with contested territories, resource competition, and historical grievances. The situation intensified after a Thai soldier was injured on November 10 from a mine, which Thailand blamed on Cambodia’s new mine-laying, while Cambodia claimed it was a legacy mine from past conflicts. This incident led Thailand to suspend implementation of the 'Peace Joint Statement' and halt the release of Cambodian prisoners of war, pushing tensions to a breaking point. While some speculated the conflict was orchestrated to disrupt the Thai king’s visit, this theory lacks credible evidence. The Sino-Thai visit, planned since May 2025, aims to strengthen 'family-like' ties and advance cooperation in trade, security, and military domains—evidenced by a May meeting between Chinese Defense Minister Dong Jun and Thai Armed Forces Commander Songwit, which confirmed joint military exercises and personnel training. The conflict has deep historical roots and is unrelated to Sino-Thai relations. Thailand’s decision to proceed with the visit despite the crisis underscores its commitment to dialogue and signals to Cambodia that peaceful resolution is possible. China, as a neutral mediator, has previously facilitated de-escalation and continues to play a constructive role. The high-level reception of the Thai king conveys a broader diplomatic message: 'dialogue over confrontation.' This atmosphere pressures both Thailand and Cambodia to de-escalate. Prolonged conflict would harm both nations, disrupting cross-border civilian life and economic development. Thailand seeks a stable neighborhood to support its China-focused cooperation, while Cambodia prioritizes its relationship with Beijing. The Chinese diplomatic gesture is thus both a sign of goodwill and a strategic signal. Ultimately, the coexistence of the king’s visit and the border conflict reflects the complexity of international relations. The most rational path forward is for both sides to return to negotiations, leveraging China’s mediation, to resolve disputes peacefully. The gunfire may be fleeting, but the enduring friendship between Thailand and China remains intact, and regional stability depends on mutual restraint and dialogue.

**Great Power Rivalry Sparks Political, Economic, and Social Tensions in Small States: The Case of Thailand and Cambodia**
Over the past week, Thailand and Cambodia's peace declaration was ruptured by a border mine explosion, prompting urgent mediation by ASEAN and the United States. King Vajiralongkorn of Thailand made a rare visit to Beijing, highlighting the difficult strategic choices facing small nations amid great power competition. The Taiwan issue reignited tensions between China and Japan, underscoring the high sensitivity of security in the Asia-Pacific region. Analysts普遍认为，超级大国之间缺乏互信，中美博弈的结构性矛盾无法因暂时的止损措施而改变, and Southeast Asian nations remain inevitably affected. Recent border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia resulted in injuries to two Thai soldiers, prompting Thailand to suspend implementation of a peace agreement. Cambodia denied the allegations and continued calling for the release of 18 Cambodian prisoners. The conflict erupted after the two countries signed the Kuala Lumpur Joint Declaration under the witness of U.S. President Donald Trump and ASEAN Chair Anwar Ibrahim, committing to resolve border disputes through ASEAN mechanisms. Following the renewed violence, ASEAN Chair Anwar Ibrahim initiated mediation, urging adherence to the agreement. He reported positive feedback from both leaders, who reaffirmed their commitment to peaceful resolution. ASEAN welcomed the removal of heavy weapons and destruction of weapons from border areas and coordinated humanitarian demining efforts. U.S. President Trump also engaged in phone diplomacy, stating he participated in efforts to implement the peace agreement, and claimed the two nations 'would be fine.' Reports indicate Trump reportedly requested that Beijing representatives not attend the signing ceremony, which Thailand reportedly respected. The border conflict, rooted in ambiguous colonial-era boundaries drawn by France, centers on the Preah Vihear Temple, which the International Court of Justice ruled in 1962 and reaffirmed in 2013 belonged to Cambodia—though Thailand continues to contest the decision. The ongoing tensions have led to closed trade ports, economic losses, and civilian displacement. ASEAN's mediation has yielded limited progress. Rising nationalism in both countries exacerbates internal social tensions, with Cambodia favoring international court resolution and Thailand preferring bilateral talks. Thai Foreign Minister Sihasak Phuangketkeow presented a briefing to 59 foreign envoys and four international organizations, asserting that mines were planted after the ceasefire agreement and accusing Cambodia of violating the Ottawa Convention. Thailand presented four demands: 1) acknowledgment of new mine placement; 2) responsibility for damages; 3) bilateral rules negotiation; and 4) access to 13 border zones for demining. Thai media reported that the U.S. suspended tariff talks until the peace agreement is upheld. Prime Minister Anutin reiterated Thailand’s stance on social media, stating that the agreement would not be resumed without compliance. The Thai Foreign Ministry later revealed that Trump informed Anutin that the U.S. would not intervene bilaterally, and that trade negotiations would continue independently of the border dispute. The U.S. continues to impose a 19% baseline tariff on Thai goods. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet thanked Anwar Ibrahim and Trump for their role in promoting peace and reaffirmed Cambodia’s commitment to the spirit of the Kuala Lumpur Declaration. Thai media expressed disappointment over U.S. pressure, with journalist Suthichai Yoon stating that today’s trade is inherently political, with 'security' casting a shadow over every transaction—a hallmark of Trump-era Realpolitik. In contrast to past idealistic strategies emphasizing democracy and human rights, realism now prevails. Coinciding with the 50th anniversary of Thailand-China diplomatic ties, King Vajiralongkorn visited China from November 13–17, 2025, marking the first visit by a reigning Thai monarch to China. The Thai government stated the visit reflects deep friendship and mutual understanding. President Xi Jinping affirmed China’s willingness to strengthen strategic alignment with Thailand, advance major projects like the China-Thailand Railway, expand imports of high-quality Thai agricultural products, and deepen cooperation in emerging sectors such as AI, digital economy, and aerospace. China has been Thailand’s largest trading partner for 12 consecutive years. In the first half of 2025, bilateral trade reached $76.1 billion, up 17% year-on-year. Thai Prime Minister Anutin revealed on Facebook that China will purchase 500,000 tons of Thai rice under a government-to-government agreement, a key outcome of a bilateral meeting at the APEC summit in Busan. Meanwhile, Thailand maintains over 200 years of traditional ties with the U.S., and its Cold War-era status as a key U.S. strategic ally in Asia remains significant. The King’s visit is widely seen as a strategic diplomatic move. Southeast Asian media have closely monitored the sudden escalation of Sino-Japanese tensions over the Taiwan issue. After Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi stated 'if Taiwan is attacked, Japan will be affected,' China’s Consul General in Osaka, Xue Jian, responded with a 'decapitation theory' and warned Chinese citizens against traveling to Japan. China’s military media reported that the PLA Southern Theater Command conducted bomber patrols over the South China Sea to deter the Philippines’ joint patrols with Australia, New Zealand, and the U.S., accusing Manila of destabilizing regional peace. Beijing urged Manila to cease provocations. The U.S., whose core interests are at stake in Taiwan, has seen Defense Secretary Peter Brian Hegseth reiterate that Washington does not seek conflict but will continue to defend its interests in the region. Hegseth advanced military cooperation with India, Malaysia, and the Philippines during the Kuala Lumpur summit, signaling clear intent toward China. Singapore’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong recently warned that rising protectionism, populism, and rapid technological change are exacerbating inequality and internal pressures, fueling political polarization and social fractures—posing a major challenge for nations to prevent. Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. faces growing domestic pressure. The Philippine religious group INC held large-scale anti-corruption protests in Manila from November 16–18, supported by civil groups nationwide. Amid calls for anti-graft measures and democratic reform, rumors of a military coup by retired generals circulated. Economic growth remains weak, and officials now expect to revise downward the 2025 growth target of 5.5%–6.5%.

**Trump Seeks Credit for Cambodia-Thailand Ceasefire, U.S. Officials Downplay China's Role**
In July 2024, a border conflict erupted between Cambodia and Thailand near the disputed Ta Mo Anong Temple, resulting in civilian casualties and mass displacement. The conflict was resolved with a ceasefire agreement signed on August 7, 2024. China played a visible and active role in mediating the conflict, with both Cambodia and Thailand publicly thanking Beijing for its efforts. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi engaged in multiple diplomatic initiatives, including hosting a trilateral informal meeting in Shanghai on July 30, 2024, and organizing a tea talk in Anning, Yunnan, on August 14, 2024, with Cambodian and Thai foreign ministers. Both countries reiterated their commitment to the ceasefire and praised China's constructive role. Despite this, a senior U.S. official claimed on October 24, 2024, that China had 'not played a significant or substantive role' in the peace talks. The U.S. reportedly pressured the organizers of the 47th ASEAN Summit in Malaysia to exclude Chinese officials from the official ceasefire signing ceremony, aiming to center attention on President Donald Trump. Trump sought to leverage the event to promote his image as a 'chief peacemaker' and bolster his bid for the Nobel Peace Prize, which he had openly pursued since returning to office in January 2024. However, the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded on October 10, 2024, to María Corina Machado of Venezuela, and Trump did not receive it.

**Trump calls Thailand, Cambodia after new clashes | Borneo Post Online**
US President Donald Trump stated on November 15, 2025, that he called the leaders of Thailand and Cambodia to reinforce the peace deal he co-signed on October 26, 2025, during a visit to Asia. The truce, brokered in Kuala Lumpur, aimed to end five days of intense fighting in the summer of 2025 that resulted in 43 deaths and displaced approximately 300,000 people. Fresh clashes erupted on November 13, 2025, in Banteay Meanchey province along the Cambodia-Thailand border, with Phnom Penh reporting the death of a civilian. Thailand suspended the agreement on November 10, 2025, following an alleged landmine blast. Trump claimed on Air Force One that he had 'stopped a war just today through the use of tariffs, the threat of tariffs,' and expressed confidence that the situation would improve, stating, 'They’re doing great. I think they’re gonna be fine.' The White House confirmed Trump also spoke with Malaysia, which had acted as a mediator. The underlying dispute stems from a century-old border disagreement from French colonial rule, with both nations contesting several boundary temples. The ASEAN Observer Team (AOT) visited the site of the civilian death on November 13, 2025, as documented in a photo released by Agence Kampuchea Press (AKP).

**Cambodia says Thai troops kill one in fresh border clashes**
On November 12, 2025, Cambodia reported that one civilian was killed and three others wounded in renewed border clashes with Thailand, following Bangkok’s pause in implementing a US-backed peace deal. The conflict, which erupted after a landmine blast wounded four Thai soldiers on Monday, saw gunfire exchanged between Thailand’s Sa Kaeo province and Cambodia’s Banteay Meanchey province, lasting about 10 minutes with no Thai casualties. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet condemned the violence as a violation of humanitarian principles and recent peace agreements, sharing images and videos allegedly showing wounded civilians, though AFP could not verify their authenticity. Thai military spokesman Winthai Suvaree claimed Cambodian forces initiated fire into Thai territory, prompting Thai troops to respond with warning shots. Cambodian villagers, including Hul Malis and her husband Thong Kimleang, reported being shot at without provocation, with Malis stating, 'I am so frightened, I am running away now.' The border dispute stems from a century-old disagreement over colonial-era boundaries, with both nations claiming several temples. A truce was established on July 29, 2025, after intervention by former U.S. President Donald Trump, Chinese diplomats, and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who chairs ASEAN. The agreement included withdrawal of heavy weapons and access for ceasefire monitors. However, Thailand has delayed releasing 18 captured Cambodian soldiers—a key condition—undermining the deal’s credibility. Experts note the agreement did not resolve the core territorial dispute.

**Thailand says ceasefire with Cambodia brokered by Trump on hold after landmine kills troops**
Thailand has indefinitely paused implementation of a U.S.-brokered ceasefire with Cambodia following a landmine explosion on Monday that injured four Thai soldiers along the border in Sisaket province. The Thai army accused Cambodia of laying new mines in violation of the truce agreement signed last month, though Cambodia denied responsibility, attributing the blast to 'remnants of past conflicts' and urging Thai troops to avoid old minefield areas. Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul visited the injured soldiers and the Thai Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nikorndej Balankura stated the incident revealed 'Cambodia's utter lack of sincerity,' demanding an apology, a thorough investigation, and preventive measures. As a result, Thailand will indefinitely postpone the return of 18 Cambodian soldiers held since the July conflict. The ceasefire, initially mediated by Malaysia and finalized during the ASEAN summit in October under pressure from President Trump—who threatened to withhold trade privileges—has been criticized by Matthew Wheeler, Southeast Asia senior analyst at the International Crisis Group, as a deal designed to placate Trump rather than resolve the underlying conflict. Wheeler noted the agreement was predictable to fail due to its transactional nature and Thailand’s strong nationalist sentiment, which hinders conciliatory diplomacy. Despite some progress in removing heavy weapons and land mines, the incident has reignited tensions. Cambodia reaffirmed its commitment to peace and civilian safety.

**Thailand and Cambodia Agree to Ceasefire, but Doubts Remain**
Thailand and Cambodia agreed to an unconditional ceasefire after five days of deadly clashes, but doubts remain about whether the truce will hold. The agreement, reached on July 28, 2025, was met with cautious optimism. The border dispute has left at least 35 soldiers and civilians dead and forced the evacuation of 200,000 people in both countries. Zachary Abuza, a professor at the National War College in Washington, believes that both sides have achieved most of their objectives and that the truce could hold, despite possible sporadic gunfire. However, the Thai military has accused the Cambodian forces of violating the ceasefire in several areas, which the Cambodian Ministry of Defense has denied. Matthew Wheeler, a senior analyst at the International Crisis Group in Bangkok, highlights the lack of clarity on how the ceasefire will be supervised, which could hinder the agreement. Paul Chambers, an analyst at the Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore, notes that without third-party supervision, it is difficult for any ceasefire agreement to be effectively implemented. The US has threatened to delay trade negotiations with both countries over tariffs unless they agree to end the clashes. According to Wheeler, the US threats have influenced Thailand's stance, which had previously rejected Malaysia's mediation offer.

**Thailand and Cambodia Engage in Sixth Day of Border Clashes**
Tensions between Thailand and Cambodia continue to escalate, with the two countries engaging in border clashes for the sixth consecutive day, despite an immediate and unconditional ceasefire agreement reached in Malaysia the previous day. According to the Thai army, Cambodia violated the truce on Tuesday, prompting Thailand to respond accordingly. This is the same phrase used on July 24, when both countries' military forces blamed each other for initiating an attack. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet stated on Facebook, 'The front line has calmed down after the ceasefire at midnight.' However, during a meeting in Malaysia with Thailand's interim Prime Minister Phumtham Wechayachai, each side questioned the other's sincerity, as their recent speeches have shown little consistency. The current conflict has resulted in 38 fatalities, dozens of injuries, and the displacement of nearly 300,000 people. The dispute combines unresolved historical issues, as the border was mapped by France in 1907, but still has several undemarcated points, which have led to clashes over the years. The current escalation is one of the bloodiest clashes between the two Southeast Asian neighbors, who have attacked each other this time with fighter jets, artillery, tanks, and infantry. Cambodia has taken the territorial dispute to the International Court of Justice, citing a desire for a peaceful solution based on international law, while Bangkok has advocated for a bilateral agreement. A meeting between the two armies in a disputed border area on May 28 ended in a fight that killed a Cambodian soldier. On July 23, a Thai soldier lost his right leg after stepping on a landmine in a border area in Ubon Ratchathani. International organizations and countries have urged the governments to resolve the issue through dialogue, but it remains to be seen whether the words and actions of both sides will align.

**Thailand and Cambodia Agree to Ceasefire After Five Days of Border Clashes**
Thailand and Cambodia have agreed to an 'immediate and unconditional' ceasefire, effective from midnight, ending five days of intense border clashes that killed 35 people and forced the evacuation of nearly 300,000 people. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced the agreement as the president of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), after a mediating meeting between the prime ministers of Thailand and Cambodia, Phumtham Wechayachai and Hun Manet, respectively. Anwar said, 'An immediate and unconditional ceasefire, effective from 24:00 on July 28 (17:00 GMT). This is a vital first step towards de-escalation and the restoration of peace and security.' The Malaysian leader highlighted that the conversations were positive and concluded with a mutual commitment to restore peace and security in the affected border areas. To consolidate the de-escalation, at least two bilateral meetings are scheduled: a meeting on Tuesday between military leaders from both countries and a second meeting planned for August 4. Hun Manet thanked US President Donald Trump's mediation and China's participation as an observer in the conversations. 'Let our bilateral discussions return to normal in our relationship,' the Cambodian leader expressed. Phumtham Wechayachai, acting as interim prime minister due to Paetongtarn Shinawatra's suspension, thanked the mediation and highlighted the agreement as 'a peaceful resolution to protect sovereignty and human life.' The clashes began on July 24 after weeks of increasing border tensions. Both armies accused each other of initiating the attacks, which involved heavy artillery including F-16 fighter jets and BM-21 rockets. The conflict left a toll of 35 deaths: 22 from the Thai side (14 civilians and 8 soldiers) and 13 from the Cambodian side (8 civilians and 5 military personnel). Additionally, dozens of people were injured and approximately 291,000 displaced, with over 156,000 in Thailand and around 135,000 in Cambodia. The humanitarian crisis generated by the clashes forced the authorities of both countries to establish massive evacuation centers to protect trapped civilians in the conflict zone. UN Secretary-General António Guterres celebrated the ceasefire as 'a positive step' towards a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

summary:
Across the nine expert perspectives, there is consensus that the situation on the Thailand-Cambodia border is highly volatile, with a fragile ceasefire frequently violated by low-level skirmishes, fatal incidents, and accusations from both sides. All experts note that recent events (landmine explosions, shootings, and intermittent fatalities) reveal the tenuous nature of the peace agreement post-July 2025 deadly clash, but that no incident since then has (yet) resulted in three or more fatalities in a single event.

The majority of forecasters identify several key factors raising the risk of a deadly clash: recurring and escalating border incidents, the lack of robust third-party monitoring, entrenched historical grievances and nationalism, and weakened or suspended ceasefire mechanisms. In particular, domestic political incentives and ambiguous chain of command are seen as potential triggers for a larger incident.

However, all perspectives also emphasize several moderating influences lowering the probability: the strong involvement of external mediators (ASEAN, US, China), diplomatic and economic incentives for restraint, and the short time window remaining before the question resolves (about 6 weeks). Historical base rates indicate these deadly events are unusual in such short periods, though recent cycles of violence have elevated the background risk.

Individual probability estimates for a qualifying deadly clash (three or more fatalities between military/law enforcement/paramilitary of both countries before January 1, 2026) range from 23% (Southeast Asian Studies, ASEAN regionalism) to 55% (Military Intelligence). Most experts converge in the 27–38% range, with only one (Military Intelligence) going moderately higher, citing heightened volatility and fragile peace mechanisms. Common low-probability scenarios involve continued minor clashes without mass casualties, sustained by international mediation and crisis management. High-probability scenarios involve rapid escalation from an isolated incident (mine explosion, miscalculation, or local commander overreaction) before diplomatic actors can intervene.

In sum, the expert consensus is that the probability of another deadly clash remains significantly elevated relative to peacetime norms due to current volatility, but the combination of mediation, mutual restraint, international scrutiny, and the limited resolution window means the risk remains well below certainty—generally one-in-four to one-in-three chance, with moderate outliers on both ends.
forecasters: Southeast Asian Studies (Postcolonial Border Dispute Analysis)
